title: Ticket #4594: Fix time-slicing for ClassAd iterator
description:
We took a shortcut in the ClassAd iterator implementation when it comes to time slicing.

The query protocol returns to DC whenever there is blocking on the network socket when writing out a matching ad. However, if we are iterating through the ClassAd log and there are no matching ads, we periodically need to return to DC to prevent the query from significantly blocking the schedd.

To "periodically" return, we simply return once every 1000 non-matching ads. This isn't a great metric - could be quite disjoint from actual wall clock time. In the example of a very busy schedd with a million jobs, this means we would return to DC (and hence wait to get rescheduled) 1000 times

We should switch to actually timing things - spending a fixed amount of time in rejecting ads.
remarks:
2014-Sep-16 21:20:02 by bbockelm:
For example - my VM development box takes 6 ms to iterate through 10k ClassAds. When done with an iterator which is actually aware of wallclock time, this fits comfortably without returning to DC (and does not cause excessive blocking). In the current code, this would have returned to DC 10 times.

If we allow up to a second of blocking before forcing the iterator to return to DC, at these rates, we would be able to get through one million ads.
